Union

The union of two sets \(A\) and \(B\) is a set which contains all the elements of \(A\) together with all the elements of \(B\). We write \(A \cup B\) to denote the union of \(A\) and \(B\). We can describe the set \(A \cup B\) formally by:

Key Point

\(A \cup B = \{x: x \in A \hbox{ or }x \in B \hbox{ or both}\}\).


Thus the elements of the set \(A \cup B\) are those quantities \(x\) such that \(x\) is a member of \(A\) or a member of \(B\) or a member of both \(A\) and \(B\). The deeply shaded areas of the figures below represents \(A \cup B\).

In Figure (a) the sets intersect, whereas in Figure (b) the sets have no region in common. We say they are disjoint.

Example

Given \(A = \{0,1\}\), \(B = \{1,2,3\}\) and \(C = \{2,3,4,5\}\) write down

  1. \(A \cup B\)
  2. \(A \cup C\)
  3. \(B \cup C\)

Solution

  1. \(A \cup B = \{0,1,2,3\}\).
  2. \(A \cup C = \{0,1,2,3,4,5\}\).
  3. \(B \cup C =\{1,2,3,4,5\}\).

Recall that there is no need to repeat elements in a set. Clearly the order of the union is unimportant so \(A \cup B = B \cup A\).
